sections.purpose: To describe the standard operating procedure for the operation of Thermogravimetric Analyzer (TGA) for determination of weight changes in pharmaceutical materials as a function of temperature or time, useful for moisture content, decomposition, and thermal stability studies.
sections.scope: Applicable to thermogravimetric analysis activities carried out in the Central Instrumentation.
procedure: Ensure the instrument is installed in a stable environment with adequate ventilation.
Check that the purge gas supply (nitrogen or argon) has sufficient pressure.
Power ON the TGA instrument and initialize the control software.
Allow the furnace and balance to stabilize at ambient temperature.
Perform temperature calibration using certified metal standards (e.g., Curie point standards).
Perform weight calibration using certified calibration weights.
Verify that calibration results are within acceptable tolerance limits.
Clean the sample pan and ensure it is dry and free from residues.
Tare the balance with an empty sample pan in place.
Accurately weigh 5-20 mg of sample using an analytical balance.
Transfer the sample carefully into the TGA sample pan.
Place the sample pan on the balance hook or platform carefully.
Close the furnace and ensure proper sealing.
Set the purge gas flow rate according to the method requirements.
Program the heating profile including start temperature, end temperature, and heating rate.
Set additional parameters such as isothermal holds if required.
Start the analysis and monitor initial weight stability.
Allow the TGA run to complete following the programmed temperature profile.
Observe the weight loss curve (TG) and derivative weight loss curve (DTG) in real-time.
After completion, allow the furnace to cool to a safe temperature before opening.
Remove the sample pan using tweezers and dispose of the sample appropriately.
Save the TGA data file with proper identification and perform data analysis.
Document all parameters including sample weight, heating rate, and atmosphere in the record.
precautions: Use appropriate sample size to ensure representative results without overflow.
Ensure samples are evenly distributed in the pan for uniform heating.
Use inert purge gas (nitrogen or argon) to prevent oxidation unless studying oxidative decomposition.
Do not exceed the maximum temperature rating of the furnace or pans.
Allow adequate cooling time before opening the furnace to avoid burns.
Clean any spills in the furnace immediately to prevent contamination.
Use appropriate pans compatible with the sample and temperature range (platinum, alumina, ceramic).
Wear heat-resistant gloves when handling hot components.
Perform regular calibration and maintenance of the balance and furnace.
